pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.2: At that time Venerable Pilindavaccha, wanting to build a shelter, was having a hillside cleared near Rājagaha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.3: On that occasion King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha went to Pilindavaccha, bowed, sat down, and said, “Venerable Elder, what are you having made?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.4: “I’m clearing the hillside, great king, because I want to build a shelter.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.7: “Well then, Sir, please ask the Buddha and tell me the outcome.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.9: And Pilindavaccha instructed, inspired, and gladdened King Bimbisāra with a teaching,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.10: after which the king got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated Pilindavaccha with his right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.11: Soon afterwards Pilindavaccha sent a message to the Buddha:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.12: “Venerable Sir, King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha wishes to provide a monastery worker.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.14: The Buddha then gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.16: Once again King Bimbisāra went to Pilindavaccha, bowed, sat down, and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.17: “Venerable, has the Buddha allowed monastery workers?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.19: “Well then, I’ll provide you with a monastery worker.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.20: But after making this promise, he forgot, and only remembered after a long time. He then addressed the official in charge of all practical affairs: “Listen, has the monastery worker I promised been provided?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.22: “How long is it since we made that promise?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.23: The official counted the days and said, “It’s five hundred days.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.24: “Well then, provide him with five hundred monastery workers.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.26: The official provided Pilindavaccha with five hundred monastery workers and a separate village was established.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.1.27: They called it “The Monastery Workers’ Village” and “Pilinda Village”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.1: And Pilindavaccha began associating with the families in that village.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.2: After robing up one morning, he took his bowl and robe and entered Pilinda Village for almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.3: At that time they were holding a celebration in that village and the children were dressed up with ornaments and garlands.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.4: As Pilindavaccha was walking on continuous almsround, he came to the house of a certain monastery worker, where he sat down on a prepared seat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.5: Just then the daughter of the house had seen the other children dressed up in ornaments and garlands, and she cried, “Give me a garland! Give me ornaments!”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.6: Pilindavaccha asked her mother why the girl was crying.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.7: She told him, adding, “How can poor people like us afford garlands and ornaments?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.8: Pilindavaccha took a roll of grass and said to the mother, “Here, place this pad of grass on the girl’s head.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.9: She did, and it turned into a beautiful golden garland.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.10: Even the royal compound had nothing like it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.11: People told King Bimbisāra, “In the house of a particular monastery worker there’s a beautiful golden garland.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.12: Even in your court, sir, there’s nothing like it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.13: So how did those poor people get it?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.14: No doubt it was taken by theft.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.15: And King Bimbisāra had that family imprisoned.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.16: Once again Pilindavaccha robed up in the morning, took his bowl and robe, and entered Pilinda Village for almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.17: As he was walking on continuous almsround, he came to the house of that monastery worker. And he asked the neighbors, “Where is the family of this monastery worker?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.2.18: “Venerable, the king had them imprisoned because of that golden garland.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.1: Pilindavaccha then went to King Bimbisāra’s house and sat down on a prepared seat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.2: King Bimbisāra approached Pilindavaccha, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.3: And Pilindavaccha said, “Great king, why have you had the family of that monastery worker imprisoned?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.4: “Sir, in the house of that monastery worker there was a beautiful golden garland.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.5: Even the royal compound has nothing like it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.6: So how did those poor people get it?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.7: No doubt it was taken by theft.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.8: Pilindavaccha then focused his mind on turning King Bimbisāra’s stilt house into gold.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.9: As a result the whole house became gold.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.10: And he said, “Great king, how did you get so much gold?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.11: “Understood, Sir, this is your supernormal power.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.13: People were saying, “It seems Venerable Pilindavaccha has performed a superhuman feat, a wonder of supernormal power, for the king and his court!”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.14: Being delighted and gaining confidence in Pilindavaccha, they brought him the five tonics: ghee, butter, oil, honey, and syrup.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.15: Ordinarily, too, Pilindavaccha was getting these five tonics.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.16: Since he was getting so much, he gave it away to his followers.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.17: As a consequence his followers acquired an abundance of tonics.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.18: After filling up basins and waterpots and setting these aside, they filled their water filters and bags and hung these in the windows.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.19: The tonics were dripping all over and the dwellings became infested with rats.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.20: When people walking about the dwellings saw this, they complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.21: “These Sakyan ascetics are hoarding goods indoors, just like King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.22: The monks heard the complaints of those people
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.23: and the monks of few desires complained and criticized those monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.24: “How can these monks choose to live in such abundance?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.25: After rebuking those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha. Soon afterwards he had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.26: “Is it true, monks, that some monks are living like this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.29: “… How can those foolish men choose to live in such abundance?
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.30: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.31: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.32.1: ‘After being received, the tonics allowable for sick monks—that is, ghee, butter, oil, honey, and syrup—should be used from storage for at most seven days.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:1.3.33: If one uses them beyond that, one commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.1: The tonics allowable for sick monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.3: ghee from cows, ghee from goats, ghee from buffaloes, or ghee from whatever animal whose meat is allowable.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.7: sesame oil, mustard-seed oil, honey-tree oil, castor oil, oil from fat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.12: After being received, they should be used from storage for at most seven days:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.13: they are to be used for seven days at the maximum.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.14: If one uses them beyond that, one commits an offense entailing relinquishment:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.15: it becomes subject to relinquishment at dawn on the eighth day.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.16: The tonics should be relinquished to a sangha, a group, or an individual.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.17: “And, monks, they should be relinquished like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.18: (To be expanded as in [Relinquishment 1](pli-tv-bu-vb-np1:3.2.5--3.2.29), with appropriate substitutions.)
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.19: ‘Venerables, these tonics that I have kept over seven days are to be relinquished.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.20: I relinquish them to the Sangha.’ …
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.23: ‘I give these tonics back to you.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.24.1: If it is more than seven days and he perceives it as more, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.25: If it is more than seven days, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.26: If it is more than seven days, but he perceives it as less, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.27: If they have not been determined, but he perceives that they have, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.28: If they have not been given away, but he perceives that they have, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.29: If they have not been lost, but he perceives that they have, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.30: If they have not been destroyed, but he perceives that they have, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.31: If they have not been burnt, but he perceives that they have, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.32: If they have not been stolen, but he perceives that they have, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.33: After the relinquished tonics have been returned, they are not to be used on the body, nor are they to be eaten.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.34: They can used in lamps or as a black coloring agent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.35: Other monks may use them on the body, but they may not eat them.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.36: If it is less than seven days, but he perceives it as more, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.37: If it is less than seven days, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.38: If it is less than seven days and he perceives it as less, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.40: if within seven days they have been determined, given away, lost, destroyed, burnt, stolen, or taken on trust;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.41: if, without any desire for them, he gives them up to a person who is not fully ordained, and he then obtains them again and then uses them;
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.43: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-np23:2.44: The third rule, the training rule on tonics, is finished.
